basics.name: Qi Ye
basics.label: Ph.D. Student
basics.summary: A Ph.D. student studying coastal biogeochemistry, focusing on benthic processes, estuarine connectivity, and extreme event impacts.

work.name: Nanjing Institute of Geography and Limnology, Chinese Academy of Sciences
work.summary: I monitored lakes and reservoirs monthly, analyzed data, compiled reports, and conducted related research tasks.

work.name: Institute of Earth Sciences, China University of Geosciences (Beijing)
work.summary: I managed the MC-ICP-MS Lab, oversaw instrument maintenance, conducted sample testing, scheduled operations, and trained students in MC-ICP-MS usage.

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

publications.name: Pangenomic and functional investigations for dormancy and biodegradation features of an organic pollutant-degrading bacterium Rhodococcus biphenylivorans TG9
publications.summary: This study investigates the relationship between dormancy and biodegradation in Rhodococcus biphenylivorans TG9, highlighting its ability to degrade various organic pollutants, including biphenyl and polychlorinated biphenyls. Genomic and functional analyses reveal key genes involved in dormancy, resuscitation, and degradation, providing insights into enhancing bioremediation strategies.

publications.name: Response of a submerged macrophyte (Vallisneria natans) to water depth gradients and sediment nutrient concentrations
publications.summary: This study examines how water depth and sediment nutrient levels influence the growth of Vallisneria natans, revealing that water depth has a stronger impact by inducing morphological and physiological adaptations to light stress. While the plant enhances root structure and photosynthetic efficiency to cope with environmental changes, excessive water depth and nutrient limitations can hinder its growth, highlighting implications for lake management and ecological restoration.

publications.name: Response of phytoplankton functional group to spring drought in a large subtropical reservoir
publications.summary: This study examines the impact of drought on the aquatic environment and phytoplankton succession in Daxi Reservoir, revealing that lower water levels intensify sediment resuspension, increasing phosphorus-enriched turbidity and shifting phytoplankton composition toward diatoms adapted to turbid, nutrient-rich conditions. Given the challenges of nutrient control, timely water replenishment is recommended as a practical strategy to manage harmful algae and maintain reservoir ecological stability during droughts.

publications.name: Climate changes drive phytoplankton community through complementarity and selection effects in a large mesotrophic reservoir
publications.summary: This study analyzes long-term data from Daxi Reservoir, showing that increasing precipitation and water temperature have led to stronger thermal stratification, lower nitrogen levels, and a more diverse and productive phytoplankton community. Despite stable nutrient levels, cyanobacteria have increased due to shifts in niche complementarity and selection effects, highlighting the need for stricter phosphorus control to mitigate future risks under climate change.

interests.name: Environmental Sciences
keywords: - Relationships between climate change, human activities, and aquatic system.

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
